data.title: 2019 Formula 1 Australian Grand Prix: How to watch, tickets, history, track schedule, entertainment
data.meta_description: The 2019 Formula 1 Australian Grand Prix will be one of the sporting events of the year in Australia.
data.text:
The 2019 Formula 1 Australian Grand Prix will be one of the sporting events of the year in Australia.

There's so much riding on the 2019 season, and Albert Park will be the place to be if you want to see inevitable drama unfurl.

Just 10 drivers remained in their 2018 seat, and Mercedes and Haas were the only two teams not to alter their line-up.

All eyes will be on Aussie hero Daniel Ricciardo, who will lead Renault's charge in 2019 after ending a five-year relationship with Red Bull.

Ricciardo has been there and abouts in Melbourne, but has never walked away with a trophy. He initially did in his first year with Red Bull, but was disqualified post-race.

Will we finally see an Australian winner in Melbourne, or will Mercedes and Ferrari translate pre-season testing pace into Grand Prix pace?

MORE: Everything you need to know about the 2019 Formula One World Championship

Sporting News has all you need to know about the 2019 Formula 1 Australian Grand Prix.

AUSTRALIAN GRAND PRIX: HISTORY

The 2019 race will be the 83rd in the combined history of the Australian Grand Prix, with the race dating back to the 100 Miles Road Race of 1928, which was held at Phillip Island. It will also be the 24th time the event will be held at the Melbourne Grand Prix Circuit at Albert Park.

The event only became part of the Formula 1 World Championship in 1985, and was held in Adelaide until 1995. From 1996, the event has been held in Melbourne.

Excluding 2006 and 2010, Melbourne has hosted the season-opening event since Albert Park took over the race in 1996 - a contrast to the Adelaide days, with the Australian Grand Prix formerly the final event of the season.

Australian driver Lex Davison won the race four times across the 1950s and 1960s before it became part of the world championship. Seven-time world champ Michael Schumacher is the most successful Formula 1-era driver with four wins. Four-time world champion Alain Prost is the only driver to win the Australian Grand Prix in both Australian domestic and world championship formats.

Ferrari ace Sebastian Vettel is gunning for his third victory on the bounce at Albert Park, and his fourth overall. The German is one of three active drivers - Kimi Räikkönen and Lewis Hamilton - to have won the Australian Grand Prix.

The last Australian driver to win the Australian Grand Prix was 1980 world champion Alan Jones, who took victory in the non-championship race in 1980. The last Aussie to officially finish on the podium was John Smith in 1983 - however, Daniel Ricciardo did finish second in 2014, but was disqualified post-race due to illegal fuel flow.

The Australian Grand Prix, being the first of a new season is usually one heavy on attrition. Famously, eight cars were wiped out in a multi-car pile-up at the first corner in 2002 after Ralf Schumacher rammed polesitter Rubens Barrichello.

AUSTRALIAN GRAND PRIX: TRACK SCHEDULE

SESSION DATE TIME Practice 1 Friday 15 March 12:00 - 13:30 Practice 2 Friday 15 March 16:00 - 17:30 Practice 3 Saturday 16 March 14:00 - 15:00 Qualifying Saturday 16 March 17:00 - 18:00 Race Sunday 17 March 16:10 - 18:10

Local time (AEST). Formula 1 event times only. Head to GrandPrix.com.au for the full schedule.

AUSTRALIAN GRAND PRIX: TV SCHEDULE

PAY TV

All sessions of the 2019 Formula 1 Australian Grand Prix will be shown LIVE on FOX SPORTS in 2019.

It will also be streamed LIVE on Kayo. Kayo will take every session of the FOX telecast live and on-demand.

FREE-TO-AIR

The Ten Network will show all Formula 1 sessions LIVE.

All times local (AEST).

DATE TIME CHANNEL Friday 15 March 11:30 - 19:00 10 Bold Saturday 16 March 11:00 - 19:30 10/10 HD Sunday 17 March 11:00 - 18:30 10/10 HD

AUSTRALIAN GRAND PRIX: TICKETS

From general admission, to clubs, to set seats in the grandstands and hospitality packages. You can live your Formula 1 experience any way you like.

Search all ticket options for the 2019 Formula 1 Australian Grand Prix here.

AUSTRALIAN GRAND PRIX: ENTERTAINMENT

Few events - if any - cater for fans better than Melbourne's Grand Prix weekend.

The week will kick off with Federaton Square to host the first-ever season launch event on Wednesday March 13.

At the track, the Heineken Village offers fans music performances with action aplenty away from the track. Heineken Saturday features Hot Dub Time Machine, with support acts of the likes of Furnace & The Fundamentals, Nite Theory and more.

There are also limitless chances to grab merchandise and get up close and personal with the drivers, whether that be at Melbourne Walk or the F1 Fan Zone.

There's also Kids' Corner, where you can take the family for some fun for racing fans young and not-so-young.

Melbourne’s food and art scene will be on show at M-Lane, while you can also check out the Grand Prix Motor Show, the Innovation & Technology Hub, and even the Auto Avenue Car Clubs.

AUSTRALIAN GRAND PRIX: WINNERS

DRIVERS (REPEAT WINNERS)

FOUR WINS

Michael Schumacher (2000, 2001, 2002, 2004)

THREE WINS

Jenson Button (2009, 2010, 2012); Sebastian Vettel (2011, 2017, 2018)

TWO WINS

Alain Prost (1986, 1988); Gerhard Berger (1987, 1992); Ayrton Senna (1991, 1993); Damon Hill (1995, 1996); David Coulthard (1997, 2003); Kimi Räikkönen (2007, 2013); Lewis Hamilton (2008, 2015); Nico Rosberg (2014, 2016)

Only World Championship race winners included. Active drivers in bold.

CONSTRUCTORS (REPEAT WINNERS)

ELEVEN WINS

McLaren (1986, 1988, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1997, 1998, 2003, 2008, 2010, 2012)

NINE WINS

Ferrari (1987, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2002, 2004, 2007, 2017, 2018)

FIVE WINS

Williams (1985, 1989, 1994, 1996, 1996)

THREE WINS

Mercedes (2014, 2015, 2016)

TWO WINS

Renault (2005, 2006)

Only World Championship race winners included. Active teams in bold.

AUSTRALIAN GRAND PRIX: STATISTICS

No country has hosted the first F1 race of the season more often than Australia (this will be the 22nd time).

No Australian driver has ever earned pole position, reached the podium, and won the Australian Grand Prix (34 Grands Prix).

Renault driver Daniel Ricciardo is the first Australian driver to have set more than one fastest lap in his country (2016 and 2018).

Ferrari driver Sebastian Vettel is one win away from equaling Michael Schumacher as the driver with the most wins (four) and most back-to-back victories (three, 2000-02) at the Australian Grand Prix.

Mercedes' Lewis Hamilton has started from pole position seven times at the Australian Grand Prix, more often than any other driver in this race (including five in the hybrid era).

Mercedes are the only team to have won five pole positions in a row at the Australian Grand Prix (the last five); if they secure this pole position, only McLaren (10) will have secured more overall than the Germans (six alongside Ferrari and Williams).

If Mercedes don’t win, Australia will be the Grand Prix at which the Germans have gone the most consecutive races without winning in the entire hybrid era (three between 2017 and 2019).

Red Bull will race in Australia with their youngest two drivers ever in a single F1 Grand Prix (Max Verstappen and Pierre Gasly, with 16,277 days combined).

Should Charles Leclerc not finish at the Australian Grand Prix, the Monégasque driver would be the first to retire in his debut race for Ferrari since Michael Schumacher in 1996 (Australia).

Charles Leclerc will race his first Grand Prix for Ferrari at 21 years and 152 days old, the youngest driver to do so since Ricardo Rodríguez (19 years and 208 days at the 1961 Italian Grand Prix).

No driver has recorded as many ‘fastest laps’ in Melbourne (6) as Kimi Raikkonen, more than at any other Grand Prix in his professional career.

Daniel Ricciardo (986) is just 14 shy of 1,000 points in his Formula 1 career, and can surpass the figure with a podium finish at the Australian Grand Prix; he would become just the second Australian to reach as many points in the sport (Mark Webber, with 1047.5).

Reigning World Champion Lewis Hamilton has finished in second place in his last three races in Australia; only in Valencia (European Grand Prix) has he finished runner-up on as many consecutive occasions (2008-10).

Mercedes driver Valtteri Bottas finished fifth in his last four races of the 2018 calendar; the Finn has finished fourth more than any other position in his F1 career (20 Grands Prix).

Red Bull’s Max Verstappen comes into this race having finished on the podium on five consecutive occasions, his best run on the podium since his F1 career began.

Only Sebastian Vettel’s 2009 Italian Grand Prix win stands as a better finish for Toro Rosso than new Red Bull driver Pierre Gasly’s fourth-place finish in Bahrain in 2018.

No driver in Formula 1 history has driven more races without reaching the podium than Nico Hulkenberg (156).

The only Polish driver to have raced and won in F1, Robert Kubica, will return to F1 after nine years.

Alexander Albon will be the second Thai driver in F1 after Prince Bira, who earned eight points between 1950 and 1954.

On this day six years ago Mercedes driver Valtteri Bottas raced his first F1 Grand Prix in Australia; his career points tally of 963 is the second most of any Finnish driver behind Kimi Raikkonen (1,816).

Stats powered by Opta.
